Note the red dot in the figure, you can see that in the state A, $P_A=1 \times 10^5 P_a$ and $V_A=3L$
Note the red dot in the figure, you can see that in the state B, $P_B=1 \times 10^5 P_a$ and $V_B=4L$

Note the red line in the figure, from state A to state B, the volume becomes larger, the gas does work externally, and the work size is the area enclosed by the red line, that is $W_{1}=P_A\cdot\Delta V=100J$
Note the red dot in the figure, you can see that in the state C, $P_C=0.75 \times 10^5 P_a$ and $V_C=4L$
Note the red dot in the figure, you can see that in the state D, $P_D=0.75 \times 10^5 P_a$ and $V_D=3L$

Note the red line in the figure, from state C to state D, the volume becomes smaller, the gas does negative work externally, and the work size is the area enclosed by the red line, that is $W_{2}=P_C\cdot\Delta V=75J$
The total work done by the outside world on the gas is $W=W_{2}-W_{1}=-25J$
which is solved by the first law of thermodynamics, $\Delta U=W+Q$ , and $Q=25J$
